Descr: Bug causes private chats to be visible to the friends of those chatting.
Awareness grows over volume of data collected by cars; bill introduced to afford users more concern over those data.
ClassDojo launched in 2011. Privacy concerns around the data gathered about students and the usage of those data emerged in 2014.
Apple mobile devices found to be storing locations over previous 12 month period, unbeknownst to users.
Bloomberg News reporters had extracted subscribers private information
Users who visit the sites 2012 presidential candidates get tracked across the web.

Photos of naked adolescents (middle and high school) found to be circulating in a small Colorado town, commonly stored on student phone using photo vault apps. Members of the football team are said to be heavily involved.
Call centers analyzing voice data for emotional state of caller.
FBI improperly gained access to calling records of citizens. In some cases, reporters were targeted as part of leak investigations.
4 CIA officers were embedded in the NYC police department after 9/11; 1 working on surveillance. Concerns raised about lack of separation between agencies.
Topless sunbathing photos of Kate Middleton are published; royal family pursues legal action.
Blood test of mother of dead newborn used to convict her of chemical endangerment; evidence of methamphetamine was found in her blood.
Police departments are building DNA databases of potential suspects; some DNA data is collected without the owners knowledge.
FTC finds that 20% of 400 child-directed apps provide appropriate disclosure of data collection practices.
Callisto service allows victims of sexual assault to anonymously report the incident including submitting identitfying information about their attackers.
Audit by the state of North Carolina of consumer purchases made online raises privacy concerns.
European plans for a terrorist tracking system raise privacy concerns.

Netflix released data  of user movie ratings with PII removed as part of a contest to improve its recommender algorithm. It was found that some users could be identified using the data set and other publicly available data.
Philadelphia school district remotely activated cameras on school-issued laptops to locate them, raising privacy concerns.
Same-sex marriage opponents protest requests to turn over the names of petition-signers under the First Amendment.
France begins use of full body scanners at Charles de Gaulle and Orly airports; privacy advocates claim scanners are overly intrusive.
Bug gives Facebook users access to the chats of their friends and other private information.
Facebook changes privacy policy to require users to opt out of making certain information public, raising privacy concerns.
Google, Microsoft and Yahoo believed to be retaining user data longer than allowed under European Union laws.
US pressures Pakistan to provide more detailed information on those traveling to the US, raising privacy concerns.
Security breach at AT&T allowed the email addresses of >100K iPad users to be accessed.
Emails of faculty and staff at Harvard were searched as part of a student cheating investigation, raising a privacy outcry amongst the email account holders.
Germany Asks Apple About iPhoneâ€™s Data-Gathering
Teacher in training was denied her degree after she posted a picture of herself drinking on MySpace
A man was charged with 10 counts of murder based on genetic data collected from his son for another purpose.
Request from Obama administration to allow the FBI warrant-less access to the communication context around emails raises privacy concerns.
United Arab Emirates announces it will suspend Blackberry mobile services because it is unable to monitor communications using the services.
Obama administration medical privacy rules denounced as weak on privacy.
Consumers voice privacy concerns about online retargeting.
Consumers voice concerns about flash cookies; some launch lawsuits.
A Duke student circulated a powerpoint presentation on her sexual partners while a student, including their names and images, which eventually was published on the web.
Privacy concerns are raised about HTML 5 and evercookies.
Instances of home surveillance footage showing misdeeds of neighbors are appearing on YouTube.
A US government employee accidentally sent a file containing the names and SSNs of all employees of the General Services Administration to a private email address.
Concerns are raised about the profiling and targeting of users of online health sites.
Military bases are using SSNs as identifiers in a variety of common settings like gym membership IDs, thus putting the military at heightened risk of identity theft.
The US Supreme Court upholds the practice of intrusive background checks of employees of government contractors. The practice was put in place after 9/11.
iPhones found to be storing user location data for a year.

A British legal ruling bars media outlets from publishing news about a celebrity affair that identifies one of the parties involved, but Twitter users identify the person and discuss the affair freely.
FBI agents are given more freedom to surveil and mine databases to scrutinize people of interest.
A database about needy NYC residents that aggregates across multiple government services raises privacy concerns.
A start-up that makes it easier for employers to review the social media presence of applicants raises privacy concerns although cleared by the FTC.
New business selling artwork and notebooks containing police mug shots from the 1950s raises privacy concerns.
Names and diagnosis codes for 20K Stanford Hospital patients were published on a commercial website for a year.

The existence of a list of well-connected applicants who were given an edge in admissions to University of Illinois is leaked and the university fights a request to release the names of the parents of the applicants.
Judge orders Twitter to give information about 3 account holders who are under investigation for links to WikiLeaks.
Growth of apps that use face recognition to determine demographics of bar goers, raise privacy concerns.
